data.text: Document Review History
Index
Appendices
Appendix 1 – Consultant Vetting of Referrals Flow Chart Appendix 2 – Capsule Endoscopy Referrals
Appendix 3 – Lower GI Pathway – Non Urgent Referral Appendix 4 – Suspected Colorectal Cancer 62 day Pathway Appendix 5 – Dyspepsia Pathway
Appendix 6 – Reflux Pathway
Appendix 7 – Irritable Bowel Syndrome Pathway
Appendix 8 – Rectal Bleeding Flowchart
Purpose

Effective booking procedures are an essential component of safe, high quality patent care. This policy exists to ensure that all patients are booked consistently and in a way which minimises worry but providing accurate and timely information.

This policy should be read in conjunction with the Trust Access Policy and Endoscopy Clinical Operational Policy. The guidance given here compliments the Trust-wide approach whilst providing a more detailed description of procedures specific to the Endoscopy Unit.

Vetting of the endoscopy request is an important part of ensuring robust governance methods for the delivery of endoscopy, through the prevention of appropriate endoscopies. It is also a vital service improvement tool to manage demand.

Validation is a process of checking to see that the patients who are due to have outpatient or inpatient appointments still require them. This can be done administratively or clinically which can be complementary or separate processes. Validation not only ensures waiting lists are not overstated, it also prevents time being wasted arranging to see patients who no longer need to be seen.
Administrative validation composes of 3 essential actions:
To ensure that there is no duplication of referrals
Ensure the patient has not been admitted for the procedure
Ensure the patient remains within the local area and has not deceased (Specifically surveillance)
Clinical validation is composed of 2 essential actions:
A complete clinical review against current guidelines of all outstanding planned/surveillance procedures, by consultant Endoscopist.
Review of emergency requests for suitability and urgency.

Vetting and validation is part of the ‘appropriateness' domain within GRS (Global Rating Score). GRS is the tool that measures the safety and the quality of the patients experience within endoscopy units, stipulated by JAG (Joint Advisory Group).
Aim of the Policy
To assist the endoscopy service to provide a high quality patient centred service to the population of Mid-Essex (387,000).
To provide administration and clerical support for the medical and nursing teams
To provide guidelines for medical, nursing and administration staff, to manage the vetting of referrals, validation of procedure lists and booking of patients for the endoscopy service.
Scope of the Service
The endoscopy service currently runs from 07:00 – 17:30 Monday – Friday, excluding Bank Holidays, and Saturday/Sundays 07:00 -17:30hrs..
There are currently 2 sessions per day Monday - Friday running from 08.00 – 12.00; 12:30 -16:30, with Saturday/Sunday ad-hoc lists running from 08:00 -12:00 and 12:30
- 16:30 as required. There are aspirational plans to begin running evening lists Monday – Friday at some point in the future if/when finance allows.
There are 9 sessions a day (am x 3 rooms/ pm x 3 rooms/ evening x3 rooms) plus Saturday/Sunday sessions x2 sessions per room per day, dependant on staffing of these rooms.
There is an on-call session out of hours, for emergencies performed in theatres only.
There is an on-call emergency bleed rota in place 24/7
Endoscopy does not provide a service for children less than  years of age, these procedures are performed under a general anaesthetic in theatres.
Patients with Special Needs
Endoscopies for patients requiring a general anaesthetic will be carried out in Theatres.
Patients with Learning Disabilities that require a general anaesthetic will have their
Endoscopies in either Endoscopy or Theatres dependant on the referring clinician and the ability to source an anaesthetist and ODP.

Interpreter services via ‘The Word' are available for patients that do not understand or are not fluent in English. This service needs to be highlighted at the point of referral by the GP, OPD Clinician or referring consultant. Refer to 09127A Interpreting & Translation Policy
There is information in braille for blind patients who use braille services.
A British Sign Language interpreter from the RNID may be appointed but this will be dependant on prior notification of the patients needs by the referring clinician.

The names of all patients with Learning Disabilities and/or Autism must be notified to the CNS for that service on extn 6579 or bleep #6555 2241 at the time of referral to Endoscopy, either by the referring clinician or by the Endoscopy Service so that any special needs or support can be put in place.
Vetting of Referrals
All primary and secondary care referrals follow referral guidelines for diagnostic procedures; they are vetted daily by one of the unit Endoscopist for appropriateness Withinhrs of referral.

There is a flowchart, for referral and vetting of both, inpatient and outpatients requiring endoscopic procedures (appendix 1) this process is audited for timeliness and completeness of vetting by the clinical lead.
All referrals are sent via the Lorenzo system are vetted within 24 hrs by the attending Endoscopist on the unit Monday – Friday.
Referrals to the endoscopy service come via four main routes:
“Cancer fast track” patients who must be seen within 2WW (14 days) of the referral
Waiting list referrals by consultant gastroenterologists or general surgeons following GP referral or outpatient appointment
In-patient referrals from wards for patients admitted to the trust non-electively.
Follow up or surveillance procedures
Fast Track Referrals
4.5.1 All patients suspected of having cancer should be referred through the fast track system, set up as a result of the Improving Cancer Outcomes (201)2 and The
National Institute of Clinical Excellence (NICE) (2005).
4.5.2 GP's fax a referral letter to a designated central fax number within the Trust; these are Reviewed by an appropriate consultant; the patient is either seen in clinic or sent for Endoscopy.

4.5.3 Patients listed for urgent cancer fast track procedures will be given a “to come in” (TCI) date which must be within  days of the referral. Due to the clinical urgency of these patients and the impact upon the Trust's performance ratings, the Endoscopy administration manager must be informed of any circumstances where patients can not be accommodated within 14 days. If unable to find a suitable date, the Endoscopy administration manager must notify the Clinical Services manager, who will make decisions regarding prioritisation of departmental resources in order to balance the needs of cancer patients alongside other patient groups.

4.5.4 Patients booked as cancer fast track are outside of the normal booking rules and as such clearly are not required to be given three week's notice as per the Trust patient access policy. Patients should be contacted via phone and the date should be mutually agreed upon by the patient and the bookings clerk. Following the telephone booking the patients should be sent confirmation in the post along with information leaflets specific to the procedure they are listed for. This method of booking constitutes “full booking”.
Waiting List Referrals
4.6.1 Patients are placed on the active waiting list by the endoscopy administration team as directed by a consultant Gastroenterologist, or a Consultant GI Surgeon Endoscopist.
4.6.2 Patients are classified as either urgent or routine. The timescales for endoscopy for these patients are as follows:

table_items.text: Maximum 2 week wait (6 weeks notice does not apply)
Maximum 13 week wait Aim is to achieve a 6 week wait

data.text: 4.6.3 The booking of patients is done by the Endoscopy Administration Team. Patients should be booked according to the rules of the Trust Patient Access Policy. In particular it is important to ensure the following:
Patients are offered a choice of TCI dates with at least 3 weeks notice (routine patients only)
Routine patients are booked chronologically from the pool of all patients, not solely the consultant performing the endoscopy list.
All patients should be sent confirmation in the post along with information leaflets specific to the procedure they are listed for.
Information is entered onto Lorenzo and Theatre man.
All patients routine or urgent should be contacted by phone to arrange a mutually convenient date. This process constitutes “full booking”.

If the patients cannot be contacted by phone, the booking of routine patients currently involves a letter being sent which offers a date to patients. The letter explains that the date can be changed to match patients' individual requirements. Where patients do wish to change their TCI date every effort should be made to find a convenient date. This booking process constitutes “partial booking”.

The Trust must continue to offer 2 suitable TCI dates, if both these dates are refused or cancelled by the Patient, the Waiting List Officer will seek advice of how to proceed from the referring Consultant.

The Endoscopy Unit at Mid-Essex Hospitals Trust has a dedicated administration team, which are situated in the Endoscopy Unit. The team works closely with the Endoscopist and other members of the wider Endoscopy team in order to meet service commitment and facilitate the timely and effective delivery of Endoscopic procedures.

This policy covers each of these areas however, in all cases patients must not be added to a waiting list or listed for a procedure unless agreed with either a Consultant Gastroenterologist or Physician or a Consultant GI Surgeon Endoscopist.
Forms are clerically validated to ensure they are complete. If a form is incorrectly completed, the form is returned to the referrer for correct completion and re- submission.
Emergency referral forms correctly completed the vetted by a trained Endoscopist who performs this procedure and is named on the rota.

Any changes to procedures or the vetting process are to be discussed and agreed at the Endoscopy user group or endoscopy quality circle meetings by all endoscopists that perform the procedures, before these changes are made.
Inpatient Referrals
4.7.1 Patients requiring non-elective / emergency procedures are referred using Lorenzo In patient referral direct.

4.7.2 The nurse co-ordinator then ensures a consultant verifies reviews and agrees the request within 24hrs of referral. If appropriate the request will be added to the in- patient list and the appropriate wards should be informed of the scheduled procedure and any preparation required, ensuring the safe delivery of the procedure (i.e. Instructions for fasting).

4.7.3 In-patients and emergency patients' referrals will be timetabled for their procedure at 24, 48 or  hrs post referral, related to the priority and emergency of the procedure required. Referrals made for in-patients that are not urgent/emergencies and can be arranged as an out-patient will be sent back to the referring team with an appropriate out-patient appointment.
Surveillance Referrals

4.8.1 Patients requiring surveillance procedures have their procedures validated clerically and clinically according to the latest guidance, at least 2 months prior to the due date as laid down in their surveillance planners. Surveillance patients are dated as the date given by the doctor plus 6 weeks grace to accommodate appointment, as per the Trust Access policy.
Staffing and Management of the Endoscopy Waiting List

Ultimately it is the responsibility of the Chief Executive to ensure that there are systems in place for the effective management of patients on the waiting list. As part of the Directorate of Medicine the responsibility lies with the Clinical Director for medicine, the Clinical Lead for Endoscopy, who delegates this responsibility to the administrative lead for endoscopy. Where problems emerge, it is the responsibility of the Administrative lead to co-ordinate and implements actions to address the situation and ensure that patients are booked effectively. Where problems cannot be solved locally, it is the responsibility of the administrative lead to escalate his or her concerns to the Clinical Lead and Lead Nurse who will take action as required.
There is a named Administrative Lead for Endoscopy.

Effective waiting list management is the product of good multidisciplinary team working, where obstacles to good practice can be discussed and managed by all professions. The waiting list should be reported on as a standing agenda item at monthly team meetings chaired by the Clinical Lead and/or Lead Nurse.

The Endoscopy Unit operates a pooled waiting list, where all gastroenterologists and GI Surgical Endoscopist have agreed that patients they list can be treated by anyone in the team. The administrative lead will ensure that patients are booked chronologically from the pool of all patients, not solely the consultant performing the endoscopy list. Issues with the pooling of endoscopy lists and regular validation of waiting lists are fed back to the team via e-mail and in the monthly user group meetings.

The planned waiting list should also be reviewed on a weekly basis by the Administrative lead to ensure that no patients are waiting longer for a repeat procedure than stipulated by the Endoscopist at the time of the initial procedure.
The administrative lead has 5 reception/patient access staff that Cover the endoscopy reception areas and waiting list.
The Endoscopy waiting list has a management system that records all new, and recall (planned and surveillance) patients.
Waits for urgent endoscopy procedures are <2 weeks.
Waits for surveillance procedures should be within 6 weeks of the due date.
Waits for routine endoscopy procedures are <6 weeks.
There is pooling of endoscopy lists to reduce the risk of breaches occurring.
Capacity is flexed according to demand and ensures no breaches occur.
There is daily administrative validation of waiting list.
Waiting list information is cascaded to the whole endoscopy team at the monthly endoscopy user group meetings.
Patients are offered a choice of dates to attend their procedure.
Patients are informed of their endoscopy appointment by both telephone and letter.
5.16.5 Patients are called and sent a text message from Netcall to remind them of their forthcoming appointment, on a 7-5-2 basis.

Patients that DNA (Do Not Attend) are recorded on the system and this is audited, as are cancellations and results of the audits and patient feedback given are discussed at the monthly Endoscopy user group meetings.
Changes suggested to the booking service and all other aspects of the endoscopy service are implemented within 3 months of feedback to the monthly user group meeting.
Emails are sent out to all Endoscopists when sessions are cancelled or become vacant, for offers of cover, to avoid patients being cancelled.
There is no discrimination of patients as for procedures at referral, booking or procedure in relation to gender, age or nationality.

We do ask that patients with disabilities and special needs are highlighted at referral in order to prepare both us and the patient, to have a more effective journey through their endoscopy procedure.
Waiting List Validation
Extensive administrative and clinical validation of waiting lists took place to optimise the use of endoscopy capacity as waiting times reduced.
Validation of the endoscopy  week pathway lists takes place weekly. Validation of the surveillance patients lists takes place monthly.
The average waiting times for endoscopy patients is currently around 6 weeks for routine and 2 weeks for urgent cases.

Clinical validation should be undertaken for planned repeat procedures by a consultant. The consultant should review patient information to establish if endoscopy is still appropriate. In validating patients they should consider the latest BSG guidance.
Allocation and Size of Lists
In accordance with British Society of Gastroenterologists (BSG) guidelines endoscopy lists are regulated to ensure that's lists are not overbooked and that Endoscopist
have time to perform safe and thorough examinations.
To enable lists to be booked consistently, procedures are allocated a number of points which represent the average time required to complete the procedure. These points are listed below:
Lists are booked to a maximum of 12 points.
Therapeutic slots are requested by the consultant at time of booking the procedure.
The proportion to be reserved for emergency and planned patients is currently under review and will be agreed jointly by the management and clinical staff via the Endoscopy Team Meeting.

Training lists are an essential part of the development of medical and other staff learning to be Endoscopist. Training lists should be clearly noted as such and reduced accordingly. The number of patients booked should be decided upon by the supervising consultant and will vary according to the experience of the trainee.
Communicating Results to Referrer
All cancer pathology reports are referred to MDT on day of receipt, or sent direct to MDT from the pathology department.
All endoscopy reports are dispatched on day of procedure, all pathology specimens are sent with next available transport to the laboratory (same day).
Where appropriate patients are given a copy of the report and a personal patient centred report if abnormalities are found.
Follow on reports is returned to Endoscopist for a final report – this is then returned to referrer within 5 working days.
Where appropriate are faxed to referrer on the same day, or viewed via the IT Review system.

When clinicians are on leave, reports are sent to the consultant covering for that person on leave, to ensure that all pathology reports are read and communicated back to the GP/Patient within 5 working days.
Clinical Pathways (see appendices)
Capsule endoscopy (2)
Lower GI Pathway – non-urgent (3)
Suspected Colorectal Cancer – 62 day pathway (4) Dyspepsia (5)
Reflux (6)
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (7)
Rectal Bleeding (8)
Training
Staff training will be delivered in line with the Mandatory Training Policy.
All administration staff training to be competency based.
All staff to have up to date mandatory training within working hours.
All staff will attend Trust Mandatory Training Days as specified.
In addition education for medical, nursing and support staff within the Endoscopy Services is the responsibility of each staff member, utilising both in-house and external resources.
It is the responsibility of the management team to encourage and support “life long learning” as identified in each staffs' appraisal.
The hospital has a library facility for the use of all staff.
Staff is expected to use the e-learning facilities wherever possible.
Responsibilities
The Chief Executive is ultimately responsible for the endoscopy service provided within the Trust
The Assistant Chief Executive is operationally responsible for all decisions and/or changes made to the Endoscopy service.
The Head of Nursing for Surgery is responsible for the nursing staff in Endoscopy Services.
The Matron for Endoscopy is responsible for the day to day running of the endoscopy service.
Finance Lead for Endoscopy services sits within the Diagnostics and therapies Directorate, and liaises with the Clinical Lead (CL) for Endoscopy and the Senior Sister/Matron for Endoscopy.

The Administrative Lead co-ordinates the booking process and ensures that patients are booked according to this policy. They are also responsible for monitoring and avoiding all potential breaches of waiting lists, by escalating the relevant information to their senior managers in a timely manner.
All Endoscopy staff is accountable and responsible for patient care within the Endoscopy services as per their Trust contract.
Equality and Diversity
The Trust is committed to commit to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
The arrangements for special needs patients are set out in the Scope section.
Process Monitoring
The vetting process is audited annually to check the timeliness and completeness of the information, and results presented to the local CCG.
Auditable Outcomes
Annual audit of Barrett's Oesophagitisendoscoped; and numbers of adenocarcinoma arising from follow up group and initial presentation group.

Annual audit of polyps detected at endoscopy to establish number of endoscopies where polyps are found and the histological features of those polyps detected. Failure to retrieve polyps is documented on reports.
The number of specimens taken for histology is documented and audited. This is compared to the number of polyps and abnormal mucosal appearances noted at endoscopy.
The number of perforations and post polypectomy bleeds requiring repeat endoscopy within 2 weeks is audited.
There is an annual 30day mortality audit plus an audit of re-admissions within 8 days Of discharge home post endoscopic procedure, as part of GRS & JAG criteria.
On Decontamination of Equipment
Quarterly review of reported machine failures, and maintenance activity are documented (log book with machine).
Quarterly review of print out errors listed. Review of non-planned call out causes.
Quarterly action plan for all decontamination under performance episodes to be completed within 12 weeks.
Significant decontamination failures action plan is immediate cessation of activity.
On Actions on Adverse Events
Quarterly review of Datix reports
Quarterly action plan with implementation deadline of 12 weeks for those reports.
Where adverse events are linked to insufficient resources, reference is made to risk management team and entered on ‘at risk' register.
Clinical validation of Gastroscopy, Sigmoidoscopy& Colonoscopy
An annual audit (April each year) of numbers of procedures, numbers of abnormal endoscopies and completion rates is documented.
The results of this audit are circulated to all the Endoscopist.

Endoscopy referrals that do not meet agreed guidelines are documented at the time of the procedure. The results of these are audited annually, and linked to referring clinicians. Where there are significant levels of non-compliant referring, the clinician referrals to be vetted.
Quality Indicators for Endoscopic Procedures
BSG guidelines are available.

Audit of activity and documentation of guideline indicators for polyp detection rates, caecal intubation rates, perforation rates, post polypectomy re-bleed rates, incorrect localisation of pathology are recorded quarterly.
Results are returned to all Endoscopists.
Failure to action improvements in quality indicators within 12 weeks results in referral to risk management unit at CCG and entering into risk register.

Breaches of this policy will be reported via the datixweb system, where trends can be identified and brought to the attention of the management and clinical stakeholders. This will include failure/breakdown of equipment impairing service delivery, management of staff sickness and resultant treatment capacity deficits.
Directorate Governance Group Meetings will be supplied with Datix trend data, and incidents requiring immediate assessment will be fed back directly.

Endoscopy User group Meetings are held monthly with all staff, management and clinical stakeholders represented. The aim of these meetings is to share best practice, shape service development and actively monitor risks and performance and feed directly in to the service.

Auditing of the Endoscopy department via JAG, GRS, CQC and MEHT Infection prevention policies, ensures that this department reaches the necessary requirements for the relevant accreditation and Standards of Practice.

All auditing documented in this policy is fed back to staff and Endoscopist in the monthly Endoscopy User Group meetings, Quality Circle meeting, Directorate Governance meetings, and forwarded available to the Trust audit team and the Joint Advisory Group (JAG)
Implementation & Communication
It is a corporate responsibility to ensure that once ratified, this policy is available on The Trust intranet and Website and notified to all staff in Focus.

It is the author's responsibility to ensure that all staff within Endoscopy and those outside the department whose workload is affected by changes within Endoscopy are notified by receiving a personal emailed copy.

Joint Advisory Group (JAG)

Definitions:
Dyspepsia – predominantly Epigastric pain related to meals – can include nausea, bloating and heartburn.
Alarm symptoms – unexplained weight loss; persistent vomiting; iron deficiency; anaemia; Epigastric mass; progressive dysphagia.

Definitions:
GORD (Gastroesophageal reflux disease) – predominantly heartburn and retrosternal pain. Commonly includes reflux of acid/sour contents into mouth and sometimes water brash.
Alarm symptoms – progressive dysphagia; unexplained weight loss; persistent vomiting; iron deficiency anaemia; Epigastric mass.
